Perhaps I can. I will^play for you some pieces based
on natural folk song melodies which the Soviet regard
as democratic music, that is as pro-people music, and
then melodies that are more artificial, that is modem
melodies which the Soviets regard as anti-people. Now
I will illustrate the one kind, the pre-194# kind and
the post-194# kind. (PAUSE) Now here is a melody from
Shostakovich’s Cello Sonata which was written in 1934
and which was regarded as following the popular idiom,
that is, the idiom understandable to the masses.
PIANO^
On the other hand a prelude by Shostakovich written at
about the same time abounds in all kinds of strange
turns,
melodic tunes--. Now this kind of composition was
regarded as anti-democratic, anti-people.
,PIANCW
You know , it seems to me that this ''mother-knows-best-*
attitude of the Central Committee conveys the most utter
contempt for the musical intelligence of the masses.
These men, who tell a composer what to write, pretend
to be of the masses. What they mean is - *'I am the
masses and I don’t like that piece. So I am going to
call it anti-people.,? After all if Beethoven and Bach
and Brahms and Schumann and Mozart survived, the people
who have kept them alive have not been any Central
Committee nor any kind of music credit. It is because
of the so-called masses that those composers live today—
because people want to hear them. I have read somewhere
that that Union of Composers undertakes to tell a given
composer in what form his next composition will be.
